en.value: How was the journey?
Talking about different modes of transport, being able to understand transport announcements
How did you get there?
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
to go travelling
I'd love to go travelling through South America.
Here's a tip!

We usually say "to go travelling" when we talk about travelling around visiting different places over a period of time like a few months or so. We use the verb "to travel" to refer to the journey to a certain place. We usually say "to travel to" + place. Have a look at the examples below to see the difference.
Next year I want to go travelling again.
When I travelled to New Orleans, I met a nice group of people.
True or false?
They travelled to Peru last summer.
"To travel" has exactly the same usage as "to go travelling".
"To travel" usually refers to a specific journey; "to go travelling" refers to a longer trip visiting different places.
Select the correct definition of the word you hear.
visiting a few different places of a country or area
driving a car
being on the way to another city or country
car
Where can I park my car?
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
to drive
Who wants to drive?
He drives his kids to school before he goes to work.
This means his kids take public transport to get to school.
Select what we do this activity with: to drive
Anna took the train because there wasn't enough space in the [h]car[/h].
We call the person driving "the driver" and often call the car journey "the drive". We can also use the latter to describe how far away something is. Have a look below for some examples.
It's a 2-hour drive to Edinburgh.
How was the drive?
The driver took us to the airport.
coach
The coach takes a lot longer than the train.
flight
Our flight departs at 9.45.
We use "flight" to talk about journeys on a plane. "Plane" only means the actual aircraft.
How was your flight?
The plane was really busy so I couldn't sleep.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I've never been on a [k]plane[/k] before!
flying
Select the correct option.
coach
flight
car
While we [i]can[/i] use "bus" in most cases, we usually say "coach" when we refer to longer, pre-booked journeys. They're usually more comfortably equipped and have space for luggage.
She took the bus to the cinema.
She took a coach to Liverpool.
Our flight arrived ahead of schedule.
This means he took a bus.
This means he flew.
taxi
We'll take a taxi from the airport to the hotel.
ferry
The ferry goes once every hour.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
The [k]f[/k][k]e[/k][k]r[/k][k]r[/k][k]y[/k] goes once every hour.
Hurry up, the taxi is waiting!
This implies that a driver is waiting in a car.
We say "to take a coach / taxi / bus" (not "to drive", unless we're actually driving ourselves).
I took the coach to the airport.
We took a taxi to the hotel.
My sister drove me to the airport.
Complete the sentence as if you bought a coach ticket to get somewhere.
I [k]took[/k] the coach to San Fransisco.
drove
bike
Most people own a bike in Holland.
to cycle
How long does it take to cycle there?
In spoken language, "bike" is a shorter, more common alternative for "bicycle". Both are correct in any context and they mean the same thing, but most people will say "bike".
I borrowed my sister's bicycle.
"Bicycle" has the same meaning as "bike".
I cycled to work this morning because the weather was so nice.
The speaker used her bike to get to work.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
I'd love to [k]go[/k] [k]travelling[/k] thorugh South America.
drive
bus
Select the mode of transport that you can hear in the audio.
coach
plane
car
Use the image to complete the sentence.
The journey on the [k]coach[/k] was quite pleasant.
car
Select the words in the correct order.
[k]She[/k] [k]took[/k] [k]a[/k] [k]taxi[/k] [k]home.[/k]
How was your [k]f[/k][k]l[/k][k]i[/k][k]g[/k][k]h[/k][k]t[/k]?
The view from the [k]plane[/k] was beautiful.
car
We had to take a [k]ferry[/k] to get to the small Greek island.
fairy
My friend [k]drives[/k] the car carefully. He is a good [k]driver[/k].
driving
takes
a bike
a bus
a ferry
We got some bikes and [k]c[/k][k]y[/k][k]c[/k][k]l[/k][k]e[/k][k]d[/k] down the river.
a plane
a car
a taxi
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Our [k]flight[/k] departs at  09.45.
We got some [k]bikes|bicycles[/k] and cycled down the river.
Fill in the gap using the image.
We [k]took[/k] a [k]bus[/k] to the restaurant.
drove
plane
a taxi
a bike
a coach
We'll [k]take a taxi[/k] from the airport to the hotel.
On the way back to New York, the [k]ferry[/k] was packed.
Why don't we [k]cycle[/k] there?
Describe the worst experience you've ever had when travelling. What happened? Tell a member of the busuu community all about it!
I was travelling to ... / by train / by plane / by car / on foot / delayed / cancelled / crowded
Final call!
platform
The next train at platform 3 is the service to Manchester.
gate
Passengers for Munich, please go to gate 9.
platform/gate
Both of these are places that transportation can depart from.
final call
Final call for passengers travelling to London Heathrow.
delayed
The service to Los Angeles is delayed by 30 minutes.
final call
Hearing this announcement means we can take our time.
It means we need to rush.
What do we call it when our transportation is late?
delayed
deployed
delivered
It means we need to rush.
cancelled
The 12.45 service to London St. Pancras has been cancelled, due to strikes.
We are sorry to announce...
We are sorry to announce that the service to Toronto has been cancelled.
Select the way someone would apologise for an inconvenience.
We are sorry to announce...
We are starting to announce...
We are ready to announce...
sorry please announce depart [h]cancelled[/h] departure
Select the word we use to say that something isn't happening.
expected at
This train is expected at 14.55.
Read and listen to the sentence.
We are sorry for any inconvenience.
expected at
We say this to inform people when the transport might arrive.
Select the sentence that you could hear if your train was delayed.
We are sorry for any inconvenience
We are saving an inconvenience
We are seeing an inconvenience
to depart
Flight 4476 to Miami will depart from gate 47.
We are leaving at 7:45 tomorrow morning.
My train leaves in an hour.

In more colloquial situations, it is more common to use the verb "to leave" (translation) instead of "to depart". We hear "to depart" more often in formal contexts like announcements. Look at the examples below.
to arrive
What time does our train arrive in Paris?
to depart/to leave
These two verbs have similar meanings.
Select the verb which has the opposite meaning to "depart".
depart leave sorry expect delay [h]arrive[/h] announce
Before we move on, let's have another look at the words we've learned:
platform
gate
final call
delayed
cancelled
expected at
to depart
to arrive
Now we will listen to some of these words in contexts where we may encounter them. We'll listen closely and then answer some questions.
Listen carefully and as often as you need.
This is the final call for flight BA756 to New York. Please go to gate A3 for boarding.
They need to rush to the gate.
[k]Please[/k] [k]go[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]gate A3[/k] [k]for boarding.[/k]
We are sorry to announce that the 9:45 train to Budapest has been [k]cancelled[/k].
controlled
[k]We[/k] [k]are[/k] [k]sorry[/k] [k]for[/k] [k]any[/k] [k]inconvenience.[/k]
Select the most accurate statement.
The speaker is apologetic about the train cancellation.
The speaker doesn't care about the train cancellation.
The speaker doesn't know about any train cancellation.
The train will be [k]expected[/k] at 11:54 at [k]platform[/k] 13.
experienced
platter
This is an announcement for passengers on the 11:30 train service to Manchester.
This announcement is important for everyone.
This announcement is important only for the people on a specific train.
Mara is asking about their arrival at the hotel.
Mara is asking about their departure from the hotel.
Mara is asking about thei arrival at the airport.
Match the beginning and the end of the sentences.
This is the final call for flight RA764.
This is an announcement for passengers travelling to Chicago.
The 11.30 bus to Charlton has been cancelled.
Please go to gate 11.
The service is delayed by 15 minutes.
We are sorry for any inconvenience.
Our train is leaving, run to the [k]platform[/k]!
The flight was e[k]x[/k][k]p[/k]e[k]c[/k][k]t[/k]ed at 9:30, but was severely delayed.
When are we [k]arriving[/k] at the hostel? I'm tired.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
There was a long queue at the [k]gate[/k].
The place in an airport where we go to board a plane.
My bus was [k]delayed[/k] by half an hour, so I missed my train.
My getaway was can[k]c[/k][k]e[/k][k]l[/k][k]l[/k]ed because of bad weather.
